bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to George G. Low, March 26, 1917

div1.p: Carter requests that his paper, "Spontaneous Disappearance of Yellow Fever," be read before the Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to George G. Low, March 26, 1917
div1.opener:
/LC
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
BALTIMORE, MD.
March 26, 1917.
Dr. George G. Low,
Secretary of the Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene,
11 Chandos Street, Cavendish Square, West,
London, England.
Dear Doctor Low:
div1.p:
I am enclosing a paper--“Spontaneous Disappearance of
Yellow Fever” etc.--which I would be glad if you would read--or
have read by some Fellow--before the Society. Naturally, I cannot
do so personally.

I am presenting the paper to this Society rather than to
the American Society of Tropical Medicine, because of the higher
standing of the British Society and the wider circulation of its
publications, and I count the paper of sufficient importance to be
have a good setting.

The paper is, to an extent, the result of the investigation
of the Rockefeller Yellow Fever Commission (Gorgas; Guiteras: Lyster
and myself) which, as you doubtless know, has in contemplation a
campaign for the elimination of yellow fever from the earth.

In event of your not being able to comply with the above
request, please advise me at once, so that I can have the paper
published elsewhere with as little delay as possible. Please ad-
vise me, in any case, of its receipt--on account of U-boats.
I enclose a P. O. order sufficient to cover return postage.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (Signed) H. R. Carter
Assistant Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service, 2 enclosures.
